keyTakeAways: Torrential flooding across central and southeastern Mexico due to tropical storms has caused at least 44 deaths and dozens missing.
The flooding affected five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi, with the highest death tolls in Veracruz (18) and Hidalgo (16).
Mexico's El Universal reported a higher toll of 48 deaths, indicating possible underreporting or additional fatalities not yet officially confirmed.
Around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged, showing widespread infrastructure disruption.
The military has been mobilized to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, underscoring the scale of the emergency.
President Claudia Sheinbaum emphasized national solidarity, stating, 'We will not leave anyone without support,' reflecting government commitment to affected communities.
The storms were linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which delivered heavy rainfall to western Mexico, contributing to downstream flooding.
Mexico City recorded its rainiest June in over two decades, indicating a broader pattern of extreme weather events linked to climate change.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in central and southeastern Mexico, driven by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has led to at least 44 confirmed deaths and dozens missing across five states—Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi. Veracruz and Hidalgo reported the highest fatalities, with 18 and 16 deaths respectively. The Mexican government has mobilized the military to conduct rescue operations and distribute aid, while authorities warn of further landslides and river overflows. A separate report from El Universal cites 48 deaths, suggesting an undercount. Around 320,000 people face power outages, and 16,000 homes have been damaged, reflecting widespread disruption. This event is part of a broader trend of extreme rainfall in Mexico, including record rainfall in Mexico City’s June, indicating worsening climate-related risks.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
